xxl.core.collections.containers.io
Class MultiBlockContainer

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.containers.AbstractContainer
      xxl.core.collections.containers.io.MultiBlockContainer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Container
public class MultiBlockContainer
extends AbstractContainer

This class provides a container that is able to store logical blocks whose size is an arbitrary.

The implementation is based on two BlockFileContainers:
one serving as a primary container for the first physical block, and the other storing the remaining physical blocks as a linked list of blocks.
Therefore, every logical block stored in the container is separated into physical blocks of (blockSize-LongConverter.SIZE) bytes and every physical block stores the id of the next physical block (so the size of a physical block is blockSize). The end of this linked list of physical blocks is marked by a negative id. This id is given by the Long object new Long(-1-logicalBlock.size) and determines the size of the logical block.
The first physical block of the linked list of physical blocks is inserted into this container (the primary container) and the rest of the physical blocks are inserted into the secondary container.
Because it is based on two containers, the multi block container depends on ten files: five files that names are determined by the String "Primary"+prefix store the primary container and another five files that names are determined by the String "Secondary"+prefix store the secondary container.

Example usage (simplified part of the main method). 

     // create a new multi block container with ...

     MultiBlockContainer container = new MultiBlockContainer(

         // files having the file name "MultiBlockContainer"

         "MultiBlockContainer",

         // a block size of 11 bytes (8 bytes for the longs pointing to the next container and 3
         // bytes for data)

         11
     );

     // insert 10 blocks containing double values (8 bytes)

     for (int i = 1; i < 11; i++) {

         // create a new block of 8 bytes

         Block block = new Block(8);

         // catch IOExceptions

         try {

             // write the value of i*pi to the block

             DoubleConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE.writeDouble(block.dataOutputStream(), i*Math.PI);
         }
         catch (IOException ioe) {
             System.out.println("An I/O error occured.");
         }

         // insert the block into the multi block container

         container.insert(block);
     }

     // get the ids of all elements in the container

     Iterator iterator = container.ids();

     // print all elements of the container

     while (iterator.hasNext()) {

         // get the block from the container

         Block block = (Block)container.get(iterator.next());

         // catch IOExceptions

         try {

             // print the data of the block

             System.out.println(DoubleConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE.readDouble(block.dataInputStream()));
         }
         catch (IOException ioe) {
             System.out.println("An I/O error occured.");
         }
     }

     // close the open container and clear its file after use

     container.clear();
     container.close();
     container.delete();

See Also:
ArrayList, ByteArrayInputStream, ByteArrayOutputStream, Container, DataInputStream, DataOutputStream, IOException, List, NoSuchElementException

Field Detail

primaryContainer

protected BlockFileContainer primaryContainer
The primary container always stores the first part of a block.

secondaryContainer

protected BlockFileContainer secondaryContainer
The secondary container is a BlockFileContainer that is used for storing all the physical blocks of a logical block except the first.
When separating a logical block into physical blocks, every physical block stores the id of the next physical block. The head of this linked list is stored in the multi block container and the rest in this secondary container.

blockSize

protected int blockSize
The size of a block (in each container)

Constructor Detail

MultiBlockContainer

public MultiBlockContainer(java.lang.String prefix,
                           int blockSize,
                           FilesystemOperations fso)
Constructs an empty MultiBlockContainer that is able to store blocks with a size larger than blockSize bytes. The given String prefix specifies the names of the files the are used for storing the elements of the container. When using existing files to store the container their data will be overwritten.

Parameters:
prefix - specifies the names of the files the container consists of.
blockSize - the size of the physical blocks that are used for storing a logical block in the container.
fso - Provides an object which performs the operations on the filesystem.

                           int blockSize)

The given String prefix specifies the names of the files the are used for storing the elements of the container. When using existing files to store the container their data will be overwritten.

Parameters:
prefix - specifies the names of the files the container consists of.
blockSize - the size of the physical blocks that are used for storing a logical block in the container.

Parameters:
prefix - specifies the names of the files the container consists of.
fso - Provides an object which performs the operations on the filesystem.

getId

protected java.lang.Long getId(Block block)
Returns the id of the next block in the linked list of physical block that is stored in the specified block. Because logical blocks are stored in the container as linked lists of physical blocks, every block stores the id of the next block in the linked list. This method reads an Long object from the beginning of the specified block and returns it.
When an IOException occurs, null is returned.

Parameters:
block - the Block whose id should be read.
Returns:
the id of the next physical block in the linked list or null if an IOException occurs.

setId

protected int setId(Block block,
                    java.lang.Object id)
Sets the id stored in the specified block to the specified object and returns the number of bytes that are taken by the converted id. This method writes the specified object to the block by using a LongConverter.
When an IOException occurs, 0 is returned.

Parameters:
block - the Block whose id should be set.
id - the object that should be stored in the block as id of the next physical block in the linked list.
Returns:
the number of bytes that are taken by the converted id or 0 if an IOException occurs.

getLogicalBlock

protected Block getLogicalBlock(java.util.List blockList,
                                int size)
Returns the logical block that is given by the specified list of physical blocks. The data of the logical block starts at offset LongConverter.SIZE of the physical blocks (because the id of the next block is stored at the beginning of each block) and the given size specifies the size of the logical block.

Parameters:
blockList - the list that contains the physiacl blocks representing the logical block.
size - the size of the logical block represented by the list of physical blocks.
Returns:
the logical block that is represented by the specified list of physical blocks.

getPhysicalBlocks

protected java.util.List getPhysicalBlocks(Block logicalBlock)
Returns a list of physical blocks that represent the specified logical block. The logical block is separated into physical blocks of (blockSize-LongConverter.SIZE) bytes. The first LongConverter.SIZE bytes of each physical block are reserved for the id of the next physical block (so the size of a physical block is blockSize).

Parameters:
logicalBlock - the logical block that should be separated into physical blocks of blockSize bytes.
Returns:
a list of physical blocks that represents the specified logical block.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all elements from the Container. After a call of this method, size() will return 0.
This implementation calls the clear methods of the primary and the secondary container.

Specified by:
clear in interface Container
Overrides:
clear in class AbstractContainer

close

public void close()
Closes the Container and releases its associated files.
This implementation calls the close methods of the primary and the secondary container. A closed container can be implicitly reopened by a consecutive call to one of its methods.

Specified by:
close in interface Container
Overrides:
close in class AbstractContainer

get

public java.lang.Object get(java.lang.Object id,
                            boolean unfix)
                     throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Returns the logical block associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown when the desired block is not found via contains. In this implementation the parameter unfix has no function because the container is unbuffered.

This call is forwarded to the primary Container.

insert

public java.lang.Object insert(java.lang.Object object,
                               boolean unfix)
Inserts a new logical block into the container and returns the identifier of the block in the container.
The logical block is separated into physical blocks of (blockSize-LongConverter.SIZE) bytes by using the getPhysicalBlocks method. Thereafter the id of the last block in the list of physical blocks is set to new Long(-1-logicalBlock.size) and the block is inserted into the secondary container. The id of the previous block in the list is set to the id returned by the insert method and it is also inserted into the secondary container and so on. When reaching the first physical block in the list, its id is set to the id returned by the insert method and it is inserted into the primary container. At last, the id that is returned by the insert method of the primary container is returned as result of this method. The parameter unfix has no function because this container is unbuffered.

Specified by:
insert in interface Container
Overrides:
insert in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
object - the new logical block that should be inserted into the container.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the block can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the identifier of the logical block.

isUsed

public boolean isUsed(java.lang.Object id)
Checks whether the id has been returned previously by a call to insert or reserve and hasn't been removed so far.
This call is forwarded to the primary Container.

Specified by:
isUsed in interface Container
Specified by:
isUsed in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - the id to be checked.
Returns:
true exactly if the id is still in use.

objectIdConverter

public FixedSizeConverter objectIdConverter()
Returns a converter for the ids generated by this container. A converter transforms an object to its byte representation and vice versa - also known as serialization in Java.
Since the identifier may have an arbitrary type (which has to be known in the container), the container has to provide such a method when the data is not stored in main memory.
This call is forwarded to the primary Container.

Specified by:
objectIdConverter in interface Container
Specified by:
objectIdConverter in class AbstractContainer
Returns:
a converter for serializing the identifiers of the container.

getIdSize

public int getIdSize()
Returns the size of the ids generated by this container in bytes. This call is forwarded to the primary Container.

Specified by:
getIdSize in interface Container
Overrides:
getIdSize in class AbstractContainer
Returns:
the size in bytes of each id.

remove

public void remove(java.lang.Object id)
            throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Removes the logical block with identifier id. An exception is thrown when a block with an identifier id is not in the container. After a call of remove() all the iterators (and cursors) can be in an invalid state.
This implementation follows the linked list of physical blocks that represents the logical block and removes every physical block from the primary and secondary container.

Specified by:
remove in interface Container
Specified by:
remove in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - an identifier of a logical block.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if a block with an identifier id is not in the container.

reserve

public java.lang.Object reserve(Function getObject)
Reserves an id for subsequent use. The container may or may not need an object to be able to reserve an id, depending on the implementation. If so, it will call the parameterless function provided by the parameter getObject.
This call is forwarded to the primary Container.

Specified by:
reserve in interface Container
Specified by:
reserve in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
getObject - A parameterless function providing the object for that an id should be reserved.
Returns:
the reserved id.

size

public int size()
Returns the number of elements of the container.
This call is forwarded to the primary Container.

Specified by:
size in interface Container
Specified by:
size in class AbstractContainer
Returns:
the number of elements.

update

public void update(java.lang.Object id,
                   java.lang.Object object,
                   boolean unfix)
            throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if a logical block with an identifier id does not exist in the container.
This implementation separates the specified logical block into a list of logical blocks. Thereafter it follows the linked list of physical blocks that represents the logical block and updates every existing physical block by the new physical block. When the logical block to update is larger than the new logical block (the linked list contains more physical blocks), the remaining old physical blocks are removed from the secondary container. When the new logical block is larger than the logical block to update, the remaining new physical blocks are inserted into the secondary container. The parameter unfix has no function because this container is unbuffered.

Specified by:
update in interface Container
Specified by:
update in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new logical block that should be associated to id.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the block can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if a block with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

delete

public void delete()
Deletes the container. If necessary, the container is closed before.
